explanation: OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: The static call graph shows the target calls this function (via the table/macro). It is the primary callee that might perform object/token comparisons — if it uses memcmp on token contents (which could be null-terminated strings) that would be a MISRA violation. OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: This macro/inline is used in the target to obtain the impl record; its expansion may call OS_ObjectIndexFromToken or perform comparisons itself, so its definition must be inspected for any memcmp usage on strings. OS_object_token_t: The token type passed into the target — to judge whether comparisons operate on null-terminated strings you must know the token layout (e.g., contains char[] or pointers to C strings). OS_impl_condvar_table: The table object referenced by the macro — its element key/type may determine what is compared (string keys vs numeric IDs). OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t: The structure type of impl — its members show whether any fields are strings that could be compared via memcmp in helper code. memcmp: The standard library function the MISRA rule concerns — you must locate any uses of this symbol in OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, the macro, or related helpers and see whether it is used to compare null-terminated strings. pthread_cond_broadcast: The pthread call used by the target — include for completeness to confirm it does not internally use memcmp relevant to the rule (it does not, but verifying the symbol helps scope analysis). OS_ERROR and OS_SUCCESS: The return macros/constants used by the function — include so the analyzer has the full control-flow/return context, even though they are not directly related to memcmp usage.
